reviewText:
Collider is a fantastic party game with single player, local co-op and local competitive modes, which is a lot more addictive than expected.

There are five game modes in total out of which three can be played single player. All five of them can support up to 8 players so have your controllers and friends ready! The game modes vary nicely and I found each one to be very enjoyable.
Collider is very much a time-burner. Once you start playing you don't realise just how long has passed until you stop. I found myself constantly thinking 'Okay, just one more round' then playing for another ten minutes.

The co-op part of the game is where it really gets fun though. It's really awesome to work with and compete against your friends. I found single player to be rather relaxing whereas co-op was the complete opposite; we all found our competitive sides coming out. We ended up playing for around 45 minutes when we only planned to play one round of each mode.
I think local co-op is often under appreciated these days and I'm glad there are still games like this that understand some people just want to play with one copy of a game on one device. There is a lot of re-playability due to this and it doesn't run the risk of having no-one online like so many multiplayer games end up with.

The gameplay itself is great, the game runs fine with no issues and the controls work perfectly when using a controller like recommended. You can still use a keyboard but I found it a lot harder and not as enjoyable. The graphics are very nice yet simple, though I feel this works in favour, everything is beautiful yet there isn't too much going on.

There are a few tiny, tiny gripes so far I have with the game but nothing that stops me from playing. My first is the distinct lack of a pause feature. Now I know games like this don't require one but when I'm playing and I've gotten pretty far in a mode and have no choice but to die to take an urgent phone call it sucks. Secondly some options would be nice so you are able to adjust sensitivity and volume. Also I was hoping to 100% this but I feel the 'That's a paddling' achievement is out of reach as it requires owning at least 7 controllers which i'm sure very very few people have. Lastly there could be some form of tutorial or explanation to each game mode (I didn't realise I could shoot until reading an achievement and even then it took me pressing every button to find it out). The last two the developers have said they are working on though which is great and shows that the developers do listen which is rare.

All in all Collider is fun, both alone and with friends, and is one of those games that if you have a few friends and some time to spare it's definitely worth trying.

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Disclaimer: The copy of this game was provided by the developer for review purposes

Few words about the game
Collider is a great, colorful arcade game with non-stop energetic gameplay, from the very beginning of it. You get to choose from one of 5 different game types, each with its own unique rules and variety of amazing music in background. Singleplayer is good and challenging as it's quite hard to achieve good scores alone. Multiplayer however is epic and terribly addictive, I can't wait for another opportunity to play with someone else, it's just too good!

Advantages
Game is full of colors yet not with exaggerated amount of them, so it's pleasant to eye whole time
Quality and diversity of soundtrack is amazing, I love this retro tone!
Controls are simple
Gameplay is smooth and nicely done
Idea of game is overally good and innovative, I'm really addicted to this game right now
Local multiplayer works perfect, with great ideas of competitive and cooperative rules
Cost of it is entirely worth playing it
Disadvantages
There are no options in game, it could really use audio or at least sensitivity options
Lacks a bit of introduction into different game types, for example I accidently discovered that I'm able to shoot after about 20 minutes of solo gameplay (I played on controller)
Could use an option to add bot as other players for people who are not able to test out local multiplayer
Bad news for people who don't own any kind of controller - it's required to play multiplayer
Summary
Game is excellent, addictive and have high replayability for people who want to get better and better at it. I really enjoy playing it, singleplayer might get boring when you feel like you reach your limits and won't get any further with scores, but multiplayer is fenomenal, I can't wait to have an occasion to play more (I really hope bots / internet multiplayer will be added one day). Description also says that game is moddable. Unfortunately I'm not gifted with skills of creating my own mods so I can't wait to see what other people are capable to create from it. I will definitely play more soon!

Personal score
9 / 10
If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

reviewText:
The Good:
- Easy to pick up
- Simple controls
- Killer soundtrack
- Addictive gameplay

The Bad:
- “Towers” in Defend the Core all look too similar
- Only local multiplayer
- No gameplay/sound options or career statistics

Unapologetically difficult, but simple to play. If you have a place in your heart for old-school addictive arcade games that punish your incompetence, this will be right up your alley. While it’s core is simple, it has plenty of twists on the dodge-em gameplay.

Collider has 5 game modes, all of which support up to 8 players and 2 that require a second human to play. I found all of them to be fun and frenetic in their own way, ranging from the one-handed play of Acrobat, to the complex base building of Defend the Core (my personal favorite). Adding players simply ups the chaos, as every player shares the same circular arena.

Controls are simple, just move and shoot. You can use a mouse and wasd, but I preferred a PS4 controller where you just use the two joysticks. The action is tight, and the controls are extremely responsive; you can start and turn on a dime. When you die, it’s not the game, it’s your own damn fault.

While not spectacular visually, it’s a whole lot of fun and only gets more insane as you add players. I eagerly await the online multiplayer.

reviewText: Now, i first saw this game on Orlygift, which gives out codes in raffles for steam games, and it actually looked really fun, despite the simple premise and design. So I decided to pony up and buy the game for myself, after not winning it. First of all, even though it looks like an HD asteroids  remake meets a pong ROM hack, the vibrant backgrounds and EDM soundtrack support it, allowing you to stay enveloped in the game.\nUnfortunately if you want to play every mode, you need at least one controller and a sperate human being (unless you're really good at multitasking). And even though the two multiplayer required modes are more for fun and playing around, that is what they are designed to do. The single player modes (which can be played with up to 8 players like the rest) are more focused on survival, which is well fitting. These three modes are Acrobat, compression, and Core Defence, with each mode getting a couple more mechanics than the last, and are varient enough to not get stale.\nAcrobat is a mode where you simply have to not get hit. This is for players who are more run than gun, as it doesn't include the gun feature like the other modes, though this is not a bad thing, as it allows the player(s) to focus on dodging the bullets, or enemies as they're called in the game. This mode also spawns Seekers" occasionally

reviewText:
Disclaimer: The copy of this game was provided by the developer for review purposes.

Collider is a great local multiplayer game that is a lot of fun to play with friends. Each game is quick and exciting leaving you wanting to play again and again. It is a good value for the money for anyone who likes to get together with friends for some quick action.

Pros:
5 very unique game modes that provide a good mix of competitive and cooperative play.
Excellent controls; smooth and responsive.
Great variety of music and backgrounds.
Unique and fitting game mode selection screen.
Fast and engaging.

Cons:
Local multiplayer only; sometimes it's hard to get 6+ people in the same room at the same time.
Local multiplayer can be difficult huddled around a small screen.
No option for NPC players; It would be nice to play with friends" even when you dont have any.
Very challenging with mouse/keyboard; Make sure you can support multiple gamepads.
No options; Would like to see basic options for windowed mode

I definitely recommend this game, it's a blast to play!

reviewText: Collider is a fun indie game you can play with your siblings or your friends. It doesn't have a very steep learning curve which makes it perfect to just pick up and play. There is enough variety to keep you and your friends entertained for quite a while, but not for extended periods of time. While you can play by yourself, I strongly recommend playing with multiple people. It gives the game an edge of competition that is very much lacking while playing single player. Overall This game probably wont hold your attention over hours and hours of game play. But for short term fun with some friends its a perfect time killer!

reviewText: Collider is a jump in and play kinda game, wether you have two minutes and an hour, hop in and get your game on. Fun, addictive and incredibly intuitive gameplay. You'll get a lot of satisfaction dodging and shooting your way through challenging game modes. Playing with friends and family will have you laughing and sitting on the edge of your chair, dont push me! Music is top notch and keeps the game feeling energized and give you that sense of urgency. I highly recommend this game for anyone and everyone, great job devs!

reviewText: Fun little reto-style party game.  I had a blast with this and some buddies doing local multiplayer the other weekend.  Controls are simple, graphics are clean and straightforward, but mastering it is a challenge -- classic retro game philosophy.  It gets a lot more fun when you have more people.  I'm always looking for good local multiplayer games for family get-togethers and trips (I take my gaming laptop and hook it up on the hotel TVs with some XBox360 controllers), and this one makes a nice addition to my collection.  It's also nice that there are both cooperative and competitive options.
